content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

user_context_message_data.about_model_message:
don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.

entries.title: Best free text-to-speech software of 2025
entries.snippet: This document from TechRadar outlines the best free text-to-speech (TTS) software of 2025, highlighting tools that convert written text into spoken words. These tools are increasingly important for accessibility, content creation, productivity enhancement, and proofreading. The best overall pick is Natural Reader, praised for its user-friendly interface, support for various file formats, OCR, and custom playback options. Panopreter Basic is ideal for beginners, offering a simple interface and MP3/WAV exports. Zabaware Text-to-Speech Reader excels at reading web content but has limited voice options. Balabolka stands out for advanced users wanting custom voices, offering support for multiple file types and detailed voice customization. WordTalk, an add-on for Microsoft Word, enables TTS support in all Word versions with simple playback controls. The guide also answers common questions about format (MP3 vs. WAV), the SAPI interface, and what to expect from free software. The testing methodology considered usability, voice quality, and accessibility features, focusing on balancing functionality against the limitations of free services.

entries.title: ElevenLabs' AI Reader app can now narrate text in 32 languages
entries.snippet: ElevenLabs has globally launched its AI Reader text-to-speech app, expanding support to 32 languages, including Spanish, French, Arabic, Mandarin, and Hindi. Initially released in June in the US, UK, and Canada, the app is now available worldwide on iOS and Android. It allows users to listen to various text formats such as PDFs, articles, newsletters, and ePub files, though it does not support Kindle or Apple Books. The app offers a wide range of AI-generated voices, including those of deceased celebrities like Judy Garland and James Dean, with licensed usage approved by their heirs. The Reader app is free to use and doesn’t consume credits from ElevenLabs' main subscription plan. A premium version is in development, but the company assures a generous free tier will remain.

entries.title: ESpeak
Claude's voice mode is now free for everyone - here's how to try it
entries.snippet:
Anthropic has introduced a free voice mode for its popular AI chatbot, Claude, accessible via its iOS and Android mobile apps. This new feature allows users to have spoken conversations with Claude, who responds audibly while also displaying key points on the screen. The voice mode supports five distinct voice styles—Buttery, Airy, Mellow, Glassy, and Rounded—and is currently available in English only.

Users can activate the feature by tapping the sound wave icon in the app and selecting their preferred voice. It is particularly useful in hands-free situations, such as commuting, cooking, or multitasking. To enhance the experience, it’s recommended to use the feature in quieter settings, speak naturally, and divide complex queries into smaller parts. Users can seamlessly switch between voice and text while maintaining conversation context. While similar to voice features in ChatGPT and Gemini Live, Claude’s voice mode stands out by being free for short sessions.

entries.title: San Antonio Express-News partners with Everlit to offer free audio narration on articles
entries.snippet: The San Antonio Express-News has partnered with software company Everlit to provide free AI-generated audio narration for most articles on ExpressNews.com. This new feature enhances accessibility by allowing users to listen to articles, making it easier for people to stay informed while commuting or multitasking. The AI-generated voices were carefully selected by editors to reflect the character of San Antonio and are designed to sound natural rather than robotic. Audio versions can be accessed via a play button located just below the article's headline and lead image. Though the technology has been praised for its human-like quality, some mispronunciations may occur, which the staff will correct using Everlit's pronunciation library. However, this feature will not be available on the Express-News app or for certain special projects.

entries.title: FireRedTTS-2: Towards Long Conversational Speech Generation for Podcast and Chatbot

v.title: VoiceLoop: Voice Fitting and Synthesis via a Phonological Loop
Ever wanted to listen to your Google Docs? Well good news - you finally can, thanks to Gemini
v.snippet:
Google Docs is introducing a new accessibility feature leveraging Gemini AI to generate natural-sounding audio versions of documents. Unlike traditional text-to-speech tools, Gemini enhances intonation and expression to improve content comprehension. Users can access the voice feature via Tools > Audio or by embedding customizable audio buttons through Insert > Audio buttons. Options for voice and playback speed customization are available, making the experience more user-friendly.

The update aims to support different user needs such as auditory learning preferences, proofing written work, or improving overall document accessibility. Initially, the feature is rolling out to users with Business Standard/Plus, Enterprise Standard/Plus, Gemini Education and Premium, and Google AI Pro and Ultra subscriptions. However, it’s currently limited to desktop users and English-language documents only, with no confirmed future expansion plans at this time.

v.title: Forget Audible - ChatGPT can now read documents and even ebooks out loud to you (and it's surprisingly good)
v.snippet:
The article from Tom’s Guide highlights a new feature in ChatGPT that allows it to read documents and ebooks aloud, offering a viable alternative to text-to-speech apps like Speechify and audiobook services like Audible. This Read Aloud feature is integrated into the free ChatGPT mobile app for both iPhone and Android users and does not require a ChatGPT Plus subscription. Users can upload a file or paste text into a chat, and ChatGPT reads it back using a natural, human-like voice. 

Compared to paid services, ChatGPT's Read Aloud is praised for being free, seamless, and context-aware, making it especially useful for productivity, writing, and on-the-go listening. Some noted downsides include the manual uploading of documents and occasional interruptions with prompts to continue reading. Regardless, users find it highly effective for most everyday needs and a compelling alternative to pricier or less intuitive solutions.
